text: Ulvik Norway Guide: Slow Living on Fruit & Cider Route
Nestled deep within the stunningHardangerfjord, the charming village ofUlvik Norwaypresents a serene and picturesque alternative to its more frequented neighbour,Eidfjord.

This is Ulvik‚Äôs star attraction and you can do this as a DIY shore excursion! As Norway‚Äôs only officially designatedFruit and Cider Route, there‚Äôs three family-run farms interconnected on this walkable trail.

Then continue along the waterfront ‚ÄúTyssevikegen‚Äù until you see the turnoff with a sign ‚ÄúFrukt-og siderrute‚Äù (Fruit and Cider Route). Follow the road and you‚Äôll be on ‚ÄúApalvegen‚Äù (Apple Road). You‚Äôll then reach theUlvik Frukt & Ciderifarm first.

From Ulvik Tender Pier to Ulvik Frukt & Cideri (the first farm along Apple Road), it‚Äôs about a 30 minute walk. Most of the walk is on flat ground but there‚Äôs some gentle inclines along the way. There‚Äôs no pedestrian pavement on the road but you‚Äôll find that there‚Äôs very little car traffic that it‚Äôs not an issue to walk along the road at all.

2. Experience the Fjord‚Äôs Majesty on a RIB Safari üö§

For a dose of adrenaline mixed with breathtaking beauty, a high speed RIB (Rigid Inflatable Boat) safari is an unmissable Ulvik experience. After getting geared up in a warm, waterproof flotation suit, you‚Äôll board the sturdy vessel right near the tender pier and blast off for an adventure into the heart of theHardangerfjord.

The journey first takes you out onto the main expanse of the¬†Hardangerfjord, often called the ‚ÄúQueen of the Fjords.‚Äù From the water level, the scale of your surroundings is truly awe-inspiring. Steep, granite mountainsides plunge directly into the deep blue water, their peaks often shrouded in a light mist.

You‚Äôll see a landscape dotted with tiny, colourful farmhouses clinging to the green slopes and countless ‚Äúhanging‚Äù waterfalls that cascade down the cliffs like silver ribbons. The sheer size of the fjord, combined with the raw, unspoiled nature, makes you feel incredibly small in the best way possible!

You‚Äôll also see theHardanger Bridge, one of the longest suspension bridges in the world. The RIB will then veer into the narrower, more secludedOsafjord, a hidden gem branching off the main fjord, before returning back to Ulvik tender pier.

You have two choices at Ulvik ‚Äì both should be pre-booked due to limited capacity: a‚Äústandard‚Äù 60-minute rideand alonger 2-hour ride. If you‚Äôve never been on one, pick the shorter one. Been on a RIB before? Then I would pick the longer ride.

I‚Äôve found that the longer rides in Norwegian ports are uncommon, probably because the port needs to be situated towards the end of a fjord to give the RIB room for a ‚Äúlong sprint‚Äù. The otherlong RIB ride is from Stavanger Cruise port to Lysefjord‚Äì another good choice.
3. Take a Breathtaking Fjord-View Hike
TheLiavegen/Jobykse Loopis a relatively easy hike of about 3 miles (~5km) return trip from Ulvik cruise pier. The loop starts and ends right in the Ulvik village centre, so no transport is needed.

The trail takes you along a section of the Fruit and Cider Route before ascending gently to offer panoramic views of the village and a truly spectacular viewpoint over the narrow, dramatic Osafjord. With a total ascent of about 300 meters, it‚Äôs a rewarding hike that won‚Äôt consume your entire day.

You‚Äôll hear the phrase ‚Äúkortreist mat‚Äù (short-traveled food), and in Ulvik, some ingredients are so local they are simply ‚Äútrillet ned fra g√•rdene‚Äù (rolled down from the farms).¬†The stars of the menu are local lamb, fish from the fjord, and, of course, the incredible fruit and cider.
